answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-25-3.webp)

**Diagnosis**: Drusen, drusenoid pigment epithelial detachment (dPED), and vitreomacular adhesion

The posterior hyaloid face is attached to the fovea with preservation of the foveal contour. There are multiple confluent homogenous material under the RPE with RPE elevation consistent with drusen. Aggregation of confluent drusen has also caused drusenoid pigment epithelial detachment. Visual acuity can be predicted based on integrity of ellipsoid layer (red arrows). It is intact in this case, so we anticipate vision to be quite good for this patient.

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
One month later, the same patient returned complaining of acute decreased vision and distortion. An OCT macula was performed to investigate the cause. Please describe the OCT below.

![](/content/media/retina-25-2.webp)

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-25-2.webp)

Diagnosis: Stable vitreomacular adhesion with RPE changes (arrow) and serous pigment epithelial detachment (PED).

On OCT, a serous PED (yellow star) is dome-shaped, and is characterized by elevated RPE containing homogenously, hyporeflective fluid. PED occurs when RPE separates from Bruch’s membrane secondary to fibrovascular tissue, fluid, blood, or drusenoid accumulation. A serous PED occurs when fluid leaks into the space between the Bruch’s membrane and the RPE. It can occur in a variety of different chorio-retinal disorders including wet AMD and CSR.
